docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a third and final set of answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who took questions from readers during the past week on a range of issues from universal health care and Medicaid to the prevalence in New York of problems like obesity, diabetes, smoking and substance abuse.

headline.main: Answers About Health in New York, Part 3

docs.abstract: Answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who took questions from readers this week about health coverage and a range of related issues.
docs.snippet: Answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who took questions from readers this week about health coverage and a range of related issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: The latest report by Medicare trustees, all top officials of the Bush administration, contained the same bad news as last year’s report.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as the national economy slips toward recession, job numbers in New York City have moved counter to that trend.

headline.main: Job Total Dips in State, but the City Gains a Bit
headline.print_headline: Job Total Dips in State As City Gains

docs.snippet: Even as the national economy slips toward recession, job numbers in New York City have moved counter to that trend.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would like to limit the cost of health insurance to no more than 10 percent of Americans’ income, a significant reduction for some families.

headline.main: Clinton Details Premium Cap in Health Plan
headline.print_headline: Clinton Details Premium Cap In Health Plan

docs.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would like to limit the cost of health insurance to no more than 10 percent of Americans’ income, a significant reduction for some families.

docs.lead_paragraph: VIDEO: IF I WERE PRESIDENT ... Hillary Rodham Clinton said in an interview that if elected president, she would push for a universal health care plan that would limit the amount any family pays for health insurance to no more than 10 percent of its income.
